status_message:
"Dah-link!" 
Our nine-part #CelebsWeLost2016 series pays tribute to Zsa Zsa Gabor, whose impressive 60-year career of playing herself helped set the stage for today's celebrity-obsessed culture.
Gabor had multiple acting credits, but her greatest performance was playing herself: She was famous for her accented English (calling everyone "darling," which came out "dah-link"), her eccentricities and her nine marriages. 
The glamorous Budapest-born actress was frequently in the news as her health deteriorated and she was reportedly on life support in recent years. Gabor died on Dec. 18, 2016. She was 99. 

We said goodbye to many famous faces in 2016. 
Check the @globalnews Instagram account (Instagram.com/globalnews) for more tributes to #CelebsWeLost2016 and visit globalnews.ca/social/instagram for a fuller list.

In our nine-part #CelebsWeLost2016 tribute, we bid farewell to one of music's most influential icons. David Bowie also left his mark on art, fashion and culture. 
Bowie brought obscure ideas into the mainstream, and has influenced a generation of performers. He was also a noted humanitarian who supported many charitable causes.
The British-born visionary died of cancer on Jan. 10, just two days after his final album, Blackstar, was released. 
Check our Instagram account for the full nine-part tribute: Instagram.com/globalnews 

The year 2016 brought many high-profile deaths. For a full list go to globalnews.ca/social/instagram.

Some cities around the world have already celebrated the beginning of 2017, complete with fireworks, lights, and balloons!

Follow all the New Year's celebrations at: http://glbn.ca/TsWooz
link_name: 2017 kicked off with fireworks, lights and balloons

status_message:
In the eighth instalment of #CelebsWeLost2016, we pay tribute to a legend of sports who also had a profound impact on pop culture. 
Muhammad Ali was born Cassius Clay but many knew him simply as The Greatest. The boxing champ started early, winning gold at the 1960 Olympics at only 18.
A brash and wildly charismatic breaker of racial barriers, Ali was a heavyweight champion boxer who championed for civil rights and was never at a loss for words. 
As a Muslim convert, Ali is credited with being an ambassador of Islam in North America. 
After he lost his battle with Parkinson's disease at 74, Ali was mourned at a funeral in Louisville, Kentucky attended by presidents, Hollywood stars and adoring fans. 
We lost many cultural icons in 2016, and we pay homage to them at globalnews.ca/social/instagram and on @globalnews Instagram account (instagram.com/globalnews)

As 2016 draws to a close, revelers around the world are bidding a weary adieu to a year filled with political surprises, prolonged conflicts and deaths of legendary celebrities.

For more on New Year's 2017 celebrations: http://glbn.ca/6naqIX
link_name: 2017 kicked off with celebrations in Auckland, Sydney, Tokyo

status_message:
In this instalment of #CelebsWeLost2016, we pay tribute to Alan Rickman, the British film and stage actor who died on Jan. 14, 2016 after a battle with cancer. 
He had memorable roles in Hollywood blockbusters such as "Die Hard," "Love Actually" and as Professor Snape in the Harry Potter movie franchise, but the award-winning actor with the rich, languid voice also had a robust theatre career. 
We lost many talents in 2016 and we've highlighted nine on our Instagram page: Instagram.com/globalnews 
For a fuller list, visit globalnews.ca/social/instagram

To children of the '80s, Alan Thicke was a 'TV dad.' 
In the #CelebsWeLost2016 series, we pay tribute to the Canadian actor and composer. Thicke passed away Dec. 13 at age 69, after suffering a heart attack and ruptured aorta while playing hockey with one of his sons in California. 
While he wrote or co-wrote theme songs for dozens of TV shows, Thicke is best remembered as Dr. Jason Seaver on 1980s sitcom "Growing Pains." 
We've lost so many celebrities in 2016. 
Check our @globalnews Instagram account (Instagram.com/globalnews) to see more tributes and visit globalnews.ca/social/instagram for a fuller list.

This year saw the loss of people who lived very much in the public eye.
They were politicians who did public service. They were entertainers who served in a different capacity. Eric Sorenson and videographer Trevor Owens remind us of those who passed in 2016.

The final part of our #CelebsWeLost2016 series is now live on our Instagram page. 
In this last instalment, we pay tribute to a Canadian legend. 
Born in Montreal, Cohen's music transcended borders and people of all walks of life. 
The singer, songwriter and poet behind Hallelujah, Bird on a Wire and Suzanne had been in declining health for much of 2016, though he revealed few details. Leonard Cohen died in his sleep at age 82 on Nov. 7. His final album, You Want it Darker, was released just weeks before his death. 
View the entire nine-part tribute to celebrities we lost in 2016 by going to the @globalnews Instagram account landing page: Instagram.com/globalnews 
You can also view a fuller list at globalnews.ca/social/instagram. 

Credits: Videos by Emanuela Campanella, grid images by Global News Graphics Team, editing by Shauna Rempel

The Canada Food Guide is supposed to be our country's model for healthy eating - but just how practical is it?

status_message: Today's #tbt honours NHL great Pat Quinn, who was with the Vancouver Canucks for a decade in different roles. He left the LA Kings to join the Canucks in 1987 as president and general manager. NHL president John Ziegler, arguing that Quinn was still under contract to the Kings when he arranged the switch, banned him from coaching anywhere in the NHL for the next three seasons. With the Canucks he won a second Jack Adams award and coached the team to their second Stanley Cup final in franchise history. Quinn passed away this week at age 71. #ThrowbackThursday photo circa 1992 by Chuck Stoody/Canadian Press.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Should doctors in Canada be allowed to prescribe heroin to entrenched heroin addicts? That question will be argued in British Columbia's Supreme Court next year, but meanwhile, a group of up to 150 addicts are awaiting their first free, supervised  heroin injections in a controversial West Coast program. The heroin is supposed to arrive in BC in early December.  It's called heroin maintenance, and medical professions with a group called Providence Health Care say it's the best treatment for addicts who don't respond to other treatments. Providence got a court injunction to operate this temporary program, over the objections of the Harper government. Even though heroin is now legally administered to addicts in five European countries, Canada's Health Minister Rona Ambrose says it's a mistake because heroin is a dangerous drug, and that handing it out would it create a "throw-away" group of citizens. On the other hand, supporters of the program say such a program would reduce crime and health costs, prevent fatal overdoses, and save taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars a year. It could also help people like Kevin. http://glbn.ca/EyRjF
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
When Orangeville, Ont., resident Joel Mantel answered his phone in the middle of dinner last week, he was in the mood for some fun.

"I thought to myself 'it's probably just another telemarketer,'" the 23-year-old said.

But the person on the phone claimed they were calling from Microsoft, explaining to Mantel that his computer needed fixing and that he should follow their instructions. Unfortunately for the scammers, Mantel was all too familiar with the so called "Fake Microsoft" scam, which has been plaguing consumers for years
link_name: Ont. man records fake Microsoft phone scam as warning to others

status_message:
It was Aug. 24, 2001 — Air Transat Flight 236 from Toronto to Lisbon lost all power while flying over the Atlantic Ocean. The passengers put on their life jackets and oxygen masks, and they were told to brace for an ocean ditching.

In a new study, Canadian researchers say that memory plays a vital role in susceptibility to PTSD. It's first time each person interviewed in a PTSD study was exposed to the exact same trauma.
link_name: PTSD and memory: Canadian docs study survivors on plane near-disaster

status_message:
A condemned Ohio inmate put to death during a prolonged execution experienced pain and suffering before he lost consciousness, an anesthesiologist working for the family of the inmate determined in a report released Tuesday.

Neither of the drugs used to execute Dennis McGuire on Jan. 16 can be relied on to produce a rapid loss of consciousness and death, according to the affidavit by Dr. Kent Diveley of Scripps Mercy Hospital in San Diego.
link_name: Anesthesiologist: Ohio inmate 'suffered' in prolonged execution

Scrolling through your Facebook news feed can be a bummer.

Whether you are at that time in your life where your entire feed consists of friends getting married or having babies, or you feel like everyone is getting a promotion at work but you, we are all guilty of feeling the so-called "Facebook depression."

An Ontario member of Parliament goes on trial today on charges filed under the Canada Elections Act.

Dean Del Mastro has pleaded not guilty to charges of overspending during the 2008 federal election campaign and failing to report a personal contribution of $21,000 to his own campaign.

Elections Canada also alleges Del Mastro tried to cover up his overspending by knowingly submitting a falsified document – he denies any wrong doing.

They learn to lie at the tender age of four, so how should parents and teachers help kids learn that telling the truth is the right way to go? 

New Canadian research suggests that childhood stories, such as Pinocchio and The Boy Who Cried Wolf may not encourage honesty. But tales about telling the truth may inspire kids to confess to their lies.

A Somali-born teenager who survived a flight to Hawaii as a stowaway in the plane's wheel well said he hopped on the closest flight that was going west in an effort to find his birth mom and can't believe he survived the journey.

Yahya Abdi, 15, spoke over Google Chat to KPIX-5 in his first public comments since his improbable survival during the 5 1/2-hour flight from San Jose to Maui in April. The interview was reported on Tuesday night.

Google has officially upped the driverless car game, revealing Wednesday that it is building a car with no steering wheel, brake or gas pedal. No, this isn't a joke.

Though the self-controlled cars are a long way away from being sold to the public, the idea got us thinking – could an autonomous vehicle handle the slick, unpredictable and often treacherous conditions of Canada's roads in the winter?

status_message:

Reports of attendees "drinking, eating and laughing" at a private party at the 9/11 museum in New York Tuesday has sparked outrage among families of victims and the public.

According to the Daily News, on the eve of its grand opening to the public, approximately 60 guests were invited to the cocktail affair on the site containing the remains of 1,115 unidentified victims who died Sept. 11, 2001.

"They were drinking, eating and laughing when this is pretty much a grave site," a museum employee reportedly told American newspaper. "I don't think alcohol should be allowed in there. It's a sacred ground and they desecrated it."
link_name: Outcry as VIP cocktail party reportedly held at 9/11 museum

Residents in many regions in the U.K. were treated to a spectacular view of the northern lights on Thursday night.

Also known as the aurora borealis, the northern lights is a fantastical natural light display with fast moving light effects caused by particles charged by the sun colliding with particles in Earth's upper atmosphere.

status_message:
When a team of Google's mapping experts trekked into Canada's frigid north to create imagery of the frozen tundra outside of Churchill, Man., capturing rare views of wild polar bears wasn't the only goal.

Sure, the team was able to capture once-in-a-lifetime images of male polar bears sparring and mother bears nursing their young, but Google was also able to capture important visual data that will one day show the changing climate of the Canadian tundra – something that is putting the polar bear population at risk.
link_name: Google aims to provide key research into changing polar bear habitat

status_message:
Dozens of  families from South and North Korea who've been separated for six decades reunited Thursday.

The emotional reunions came during a rare period of détente between the rival Koreas, and are all the more poignant because the participants will part again in a few days, likely forever. 

As they waited anxiously in the days leading up to the trip, many elderly Koreans had been unsure whether they would be able to see their long-lost relatives' faces before they died.

In this image below, South Korean Park Yang-gon, left, and his North Korean brother Park Yang Soo get emotional as they met during the Separated Family Reunion Meeting at Diamond Mountain resort in North Korea, Thursday, Feb. 20, 2014.  

See the gallery of the heartbreaking reunions here: http://globalnews.ca/news/1161613/8-heart-breaking-images-as-separated-north-south-korean-families-reunite/

status_message:
Ellen Richardson is one of an estimated 75,000 Canadians who attempt suicide every year—the kind of self-harm often associated with a history of mental illness. She's undergone years of therapy, has written a memoir and, through her website, helps other people suffering depression. She's bright, lucid and happens to be in a wheelchair.

As part of her therapy she enjoys Caribbean cruises, like the one sponsored by the March of Dimes, which she signed up for and paid in full last year at a cost of nearly $6000.

But when she went to Pearson Airport last November to board her flight to the U.S., she was confronted by a border agent who asked her a question she never expected to hear from anyone but her doctor: Could she tell him about her suicide attempt in 2012 that landed her in a hospital? (She'd taken an overdose of pills.)

Read the rest of the story here:
link_name: Suicide profiling at US border investigated

status_message:
An Italian military court has acquitted an Army reserve doctor of disobedience for helping a cat who had trouble delivering a litter of kittens on a military base in Kosovo in 2012.

Army medical reservist Lt. Barbara Balanzoni said after her acquittal Friday she was disciplined, and later charged, after Italian soldiers asked her to help a cat whose last kitten was stillborn. Balanzoni said the cat, which she named Agata, would have died without intervention.

She was accused of violating protocol that states animals must be tended by veterinarians. Balanzoni said none was on base.
link_name: Italian reservist acquitted in cat rescue case

Italian artist Alexsandro Palombo has re-imagined Disney princesses as people living with physical disabilities in his latest online series in hopes of creating social awareness around the issue of disability.

Palombo, 40, said he doesn't think persons with disabilities "match Disney's standards of beauty" and said his message is very simple: disabled people have rights and are part of the world.

"Disability is part of our world but unfortunately too many people think that it is something ugly that you have to hide," he told Global News.
link_name: Artist depicts Disney princesses with physical disabilities

When pot sales begin next year in Washington, where citizens

Government requests for user information have more than doubled over three years, according to Google's latest transparency report.

U.S. authorities accounted for 10,918 of the requests, more than any other country. Canada, however, placed only 49 requests during this time period – Google handed over data in 27 per cent of those cases.
link_name: Google transparency report reveals government data requests have doubled since 2010

status_message:
In 1900, there were 220 million people living in cities, generating fewer than 300,000 tonnes of solid waste. One hundred years later, more than 2.9 billion people lived in cities and generated 3,000,000 tonnes.

Canada is one of the leading producers of waste in the world. Solid waste is set to peak in 2100, but in the meantime, it is generating pollution as well as greenhouse gases. Researchers believe that if we curb our consumerism and find better ways to package, we could bring it back at least another 25 years.
link_name: Global garbage crisis looming, say experts

Hi everyone, just a quick reminder of our house rules:

Please keep your Facebook posts clean, constructive and on topic. Unlawful, disrespectful, slanderous, defamatory, malicious, threatening, profane, obscene, tasteless or pornographic remarks will not be tolerated, and will be deleted without notice. Spam, graffiti, campaigning and advertising are also strictly prohibited.

While we encourage free speech and debate, harassment and attacks on fellow Facebook fans are unacceptable.

Repeated abusers of this policy will be reported, and may be banned.

Toronto police Chief William Blair says investigators have recovered a video of Mayor Rob Ford as part of an investigation focused on a video purporting to show Ford smoking crack cocaine.

The video contains "images consistent with those that had been previously reported in the press," Blair told reporters on Thursday.

He appeared to be referring to reports from Gawker and the Toronto Star from May – reporters said they'd been shown a video of someone who looked like the Mayor smoking what looked like crack cocaine. Ford has called these allegations "ridiculous" and said he "cannot comment on a video I haven't seen or does not exist." 

READ IT HERE: http://globalnews.ca/news/937490/toronto-police-chief-to-update-project-brazen-investigation/

status_message: Researchers at the University of British Columbia have developed a DNA test to catch athletes who use blood doping to enhance their performance, but its limitations mean the current testing system will continue to detect cheaters.

status_message: A British geneticist believes that he has solved the mystery of the mysterious and elusive Yeti said to live in the Himalayas, what we call Bigfoot or Sasquatch here in North America. And surprisingly, he's not related to an ape at all.

status_message:
U.S. researchers are announcing the rare discovery of a new species of mammal.

It is a raccoon-sized creature with a teddy bear face called the olinguito .

A Smithsonian researcher says it lives in the mountainous forests of Ecuador and Colombia where it leaps through the trees at night. It eats fruit and weighs about 2 pounds (1 kilogram).

http://globalnews.ca/news/781918/new-mammal-species-discovered-a-raccoon-sized-critter-with-teddy-bear-looks/

Photo credit: AP Photo/Mark Gurney
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
While it's assumed that Facebook helps us feel more connected to friends and family, be it through status updates or likes on your latest "selfie," a new study suggests that regular Facebook use can lead to unhappiness.

The University of Michigan Study released Wednesday found that the time a user spent on Facebook negatively influenced a user's feelings of well-being, happiness, and overall life satisfaction.

Researchers even noted that the longer a person spent on Facebook in one sitting, the worse they felt.
link_name: Study finds Facebook use may lead to unhappiness

status_message:
The State Department has warned Americans not to travel to Pakistan and evacuated nonessential government personnel from the country's second largest city because of a specific threat to the consulate there, a U.S. official said Friday.

The move was not related to the threat of an al-Qaida attack that prompted Washington to close temporarily 19 diplomatic posts in the Middle East and Africa, U.S. officials said.
link_name: U.S. orders diplomats to leave Lahore, Pakistan over threat

status_message:
A dog may be man's best friend, but dolphins can imitate human actions, and even how they solve problems.

When a dolphin has one of its senses blocked, it can use other senses to mimic a human's movements, according to a recent study.

status_message:
BREAKING: 

The Ohio man convicted of holding three women captive in his Cleveland house over a decade and raping them repeatedly has been sentenced to life without parole.

Fifty-three-year-old Ariel Castro was being given his sentence Thursday. He had pleaded guilty to 937 counts including aggravated murder, kidnapping, rape and assault.

He got the life term for the most serious count and was getting additional time for the hundreds of other counts.
link_name: Cleveland kidnapper Ariel Castro sentenced to life without parole

status_message:
UPDATE: Police have issued an Amber Alert for a 9-year-old boy who believed to have been abducted in the Niagara Region of southern Ontario.

Joseluis Resendiz is described as four-foot-six, 65 pounds with dark hair and last seen wearing a blue soccer t-shirt, blue plaid shorts and blue Adidas running shoes.

Police are attempting to locate Tivisay Rojas-Castano and Edison Rojas-Castano in relation to a parental abduction.

The pair fled from Niagara Falls with Joseluis in a grey, four-door sedan.

Officers have information that the suspects have ties to Toronto and Hamilton and may be in either city at this time.

MORE INFORMATION: http://bit.ly/1bN5TZS
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
There's a new form of protest going on in Turkey following two weeks of anti-government demonstrations.

Started by one man, it has now grown to hundreds of people standing motionless for hours in streets and squares.

The image was stark. A silent, solitary figure standing in passive defiance to the Turkish prime minister's demand for protesters to clear Taksim Square in central Istanbul.

The challenge by performance artist Erdem Gunduz is catching on with other protesters in Turkey, encouraged by social media into imitating his gesture across the country.

Here's a look at the silent 'standing man' protests in Turkey: http://globalnews.ca/news/653593/gallery-turkeys-standing-man-protests/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
If worry about skin cancer doesn't make you slather on sunscreen, maybe vanity will: New research provides some of the strongest evidence to date that near-daily sunscreen use can slow the aging of your skin.

Ultraviolet rays that spur wrinkles and other signs of aging can quietly build up damage pretty much anytime you're in the sun – a lunchtime stroll, school recess, walking the dog – and they even penetrate car windows.
link_name: Want younger-looking skin? Study advises using daily sunscreen, even in middle age

Two seniors homes in southern Alberta are being treated for bedbugs, but health officials say there's no reason for concern beyond the "ick" factor.

status_message:
B.C. Supreme Court will begin a case today that determines whether mothers in prison will be allowed to care for their babies.

A constitutional challenge was filed by five women and two babies five years ago when a program that allowed infants to remain with their incarcerated mothers was cancelled at Maple Ridge's Alouette Correctional Centre for Women.

The plaintiffs argue that the cancellation of the Mother-Baby Program discriminates against female prisoners and infringes upon their babies' rights to security because it forces the infants to be placed in temporary care away from their mothers.
link_name: Moms in prison case goes to BC Supreme Court

status_message: Any recent home-buyers out there looking to sell because their mortgage is unmanageable? Tell Global your story.

Twitter introduced two-step verification for all account holders Wednesday in an effort to improve account security and thwart potential hackers.

Users who enable two-factor authentication on their accounts are required to register a verified phone number to their account. Once activated, the user will be required to input a six-digit code sent via text message to the number registered to their account along with their password each time they sign in to their account.
link_name: Twitter introduces two-step verification to improve account security

status_message:
You can smell the oil from Wayne Johnston's house.

The scent wafts, when the wind is right, from a baby-blue pumpjack whirring up and down a short walk from his front door.

And his grass grows just a little greener in thin, straight lines radiating out from the humming pumpjack – all he sees of pipelines snaking under his property, most of the time.

This is what it's like living with oil running through your backyard. 

Read Global News' investigative series on almost four decades of oil spills in Alberta:
link_name: What it's like when oil runs through your backyard

It took more than a decade to write. Hundreds of mental health experts contributed to the laborious process. And still, before the first spine has been cracked on the latest iteration of the bible of psychiatry, the new DSM-5 has caused quite a stir.

Critics contend the newest version of the DSM risks creating diagnosis-creep, with broader definitions that will encompass more people and medicalize things such as normal grieving.
link_name: Years in the making, controversial new psychiatry 'bible' about to launch

Thousands in cities around the world are planning a series of rallies and marches to mark International Worker's Day today.

Low-paid workers rallied in the streets Wednesday to demand better pay and improved working conditions a week after a Bangladesh building collapse that was a grim reminder of how lax safety regulations make work a danger in poor countries.

status_message:
"He was a vegetarian. He never ate any meat during the entire time I was there," Woelk said of the Nazi leader. "And Hitler was so paranoid that the British would poison him – that's why he had 15 girls taste the food before he ate it himself."

They were feasts of sublime asparagus – laced with fear. And for more than half a century, Margot Woelk kept her secret hidden from the world, even from her husband. Then, a few months after her 95th birthday, she revealed the truth about her wartime role: Adolf  Hitler's food taster.

Read the full story: http://globalnews.ca/news/514473/hitlers-food-taster-tells-of-poisoning-fears/

In a mere few weeks, a strain of avian flu has infected 108 people and killed 23 in China. The birds aren't showing any symptoms of illness making it difficult for scientists to track its origins. Meanwhile the virus seems to jump to humans easily.

It's this combination of factors that has Canadian and global officials worried about the H7N9 bird flu that has emerged in China. The World Health Organization has even called the influenza "one of the most lethal" viruses it's seen so far.
link_name: Why the WHO is calling H7N9 one of the 'most lethal' flu viruses so far

There were days when she prayed for a bullet to end her suffering. When she thought she was dying of a heart attack, she whispered "Thank you God."

A young judge, Nusreta Sivac was one of 37 women raped by guards at a concentration camp in Bosnia. They never discussed the nightly traumas - their pained glances were enough to communicate their suffering. She also witnessed murder and torture by Bosnian Serb guards - and was forced to clean blood from walls and floors of the interrogation room.

She told herself to memorize the names and faces of the tormentors so that one day she might bring them to justice.
link_name: Bosnian woman helped win recognition of rape as a war crime

status_message:
WATCH LIVE: The proportion of Aboriginal Canadians in prison is growing and they continue to fall behind their non-Aboriginal peers even 20 years after Ottawa passed laws meant to reverse the trends, according to a landmark report by Canada's correctional investigator.

The federal government tabled a special report from Canada's Correctional Investigator Howard Sapers in the House of Commons on Thursday.

"Close to one-in-four inmates in federal penitentiaries today are of Aboriginal ancestry, yet Aboriginal-specific legislative provisions are chronically under-funded, under-utilized and unevenly applied by the Correctional Service. In failing to fully meet Parliament's intent, my review concludes that the federal correctional system perpetuates conditions of disadvantage for Aboriginal people in Canada," Sapers said.
link_name: Ottawa releases landmark investigation into Aboriginal people in prison

status_message:
Canadian industry groups are fighting Canada's anti-spam legislation designed to cut down on spyware and spamming in Canada. 

The anti-spam and anti-spyware legislation, likely to take effect by the end of 2013, would include new rules that would require opt-in consent for electronic marketing, as well as the installation of computer programs such as spyware. In simpler terms, the law would help cut down on unwanted "junk mail" in Canadians' inboxes and force third parties to obtain consent from the user to install any sort of spyware.

Global News spoke with Michael Geist, law professor and Canada Research Chair in Internet and E-commerce law at the University of Ottawa, regarding the anti-spam legislation and why Industry groups are fighting back.
link_name: Canadian business groups push back against anti-spam law

Canadians should live their lives worthy of the freedom, democracy and justice they enjoy as a tribute to those who made the ultimate sacrifice defending those values, Prime Minister Stephen Harper said Sunday.

Harper marked Remembrance Day at the Sai Wan Bay military cemetery where 283 Canadian soldiers are buried on a grassy, tree-fringed slope overlooking the skyscrapers of bustling Hong Kong.

status_message:
President Barack Obama was declared the winner of Florida's 29 electoral votes Saturday, ending a four-day count with a razor-thin margin that narrowly avoided an automatic recount that would have brought back memories of 2000. 

No matter the outcome, Obama had already clinched re-election and now has 332 electoral votes to Romney's 206.
link_name: President Barack Obama wins Florida, topping Romney in final vote tally

Another Toronto man is facing charges in the theft of poppy donation boxes. 

Nicholas Moorhouse, 34 was arrested last night and charged with stealing three poppy boxes from Tim Horton's restaurants in the downtown area. 

Police say he had one of the Canadian Legion donation boxes on him when he was arrested and that it contained about 50 dollars.

status_message:
Wireless carriers are setting up a system that would blacklist lost or stolen smartphones and keep them from being reactivated.

Canada's Wireless Telecommunications Association says within a year, any effort to authorize a smartphone will require verification that the device hasn't been reported lost or stolen. If it's on the blacklist, it won't get activated.

Do you agree with this new measure?
link_name: Wireless carriers establish electronic blacklist to fight smartphone theft

status_message:
McDonald's says a key sales figure fell in October, marking the first monthly drop in nearly a decade for the world's biggest hamburger chain.

The U.S.-based company says global sales at restaurants open at least a year fell 1.8 per cent for the month. The last time the figure dropped was in 2003. 

Are you scaling back on your fast food meals?

Changes to the pension plan for federal MPs will eventually see them putting nearly four times as much of their own money towards retirement than they currently do.

status_message:
Amanda Todd's mother, Carol Todd, doesn't want other children to suffer as her daughter did — stalked and harassed by bullies in cyberspace and in the schoolyard, by people she knew and by stalkers many miles away.

Amanda told her story in the heart-wrenching video that chronicled her nightmare: the taunts, the beating, the cyber-stalker who tracked her down whenever she tried to start afresh at a new school — firing off images that captured her showing off her young body, flattered by online attention from someone she thought was a kid just like her.
link_name: Bullied B.C. teen's mom speaks out about daughter's death

status_message:
Good morning readers!

How are you spending your weekend?

"I can never get that photo back. It's out there forever." 

Those were the words of 15-year-old Amanda Todd, who committed suicide in her Port Coquitlam, B.C. home on Wednesday after a years-long battle with bullying. 

For Todd those consequences were devastating. The teenage girl documents how her life took a dark turn after that fateful online encounter in a YouTube video posted in September.
link_name: Protecting children from bullying requires more cyber-safety education say experts

status_message:
The mother of a teenager who died Wednesday of suspected suicide wants her daughter's anti-cyber-bullying video to be used to help other young people.

Fifteen-year-old Amanda Todd was found dead in a Port Coquitlam home at 6 p.m. Wednesday, five weeks after she posted a heartbreaking video on YouTube detailing how she was harassed online and bullied.

"I think the video should be shared and used as an anti-bullying tool. That is what my daughter would have wanted," Carol Todd, Amanda's mother, told The Vancouver Sun in a message on Twitter.
link_name: Outpouring of grief over cyberbullied B.C. teen's suicide

status_message:
Alfred Eisenstaedt's "Kissing Sailor" image has been thought of by many as nothing else but a loving embrace celebrating the end of the Second World War. 

Locked in an embrace in the middle of New York's Times Square on VJ Day in 1945, the photo of a sailor and a nurse kissing passionately is an iconic romantic image. Or is it?

A blog post titled "Kissing Sailor, or 'The Selective Blindness of Rape Culture'" argues that upon closer examination of the photo, the woman being kissed is actually being sexually assaulted. 

What do you think?
link_name: "Kissing Sailor" photo depict sexual assault, says feminist blogger

A spokesperson for the U.S. Federal Bureau of Prisons said that Vito Rizzuto, 66, the reputed head of the Mafia in Montreal before he was extradited in 2006, was released from a federal prison in Colorado Friday morning.

The long-time Montreal resident was scheduled to be released on Saturday but he benefited from legislation covering inmates in the U.S. which allows them to be released on a Friday if their released date falls on a weekend.

Canada's highest court will rule Friday on whether HIV-positive Canadians who don't tell their sexual partners of their status should face criminal charges.

Jennifer Livingston has always rebuffed personal attacks, so when the Wisconsin television anchorwoman got an email from a viewer criticizing her weight, she thought nothing of it.

But then she thought of her daughters and other children who may not have the same emotional shield.

Livingston took the airways Tuesday to respond to the email during a 4-minute segment on WKBT-TV in La Crosse, calling the writer a bully. She urged young viewers not to allow such people to define their self-worth.

This year, Canada's controversial decision to cut diplomatic ties with Iran could merit a mention in Ahmadinejad's final speech to the world body as president.

OTTAWA – With the House of Commons set to vote on a controversial motion to study the definition of a human being on Wednesday, the battlelines are becoming clear on Parliament Hill.

The vote will be closely watched by both pro-choice and pro-life groups in Canada as many believe it is a way to re-open the abortion debate in Canada. 

Prime Minister Stephen Harper has promised to vote against Woodworth's motion. Many MPs are planning to vote with him, but others will vote in support of the study. 

The full tally won't be taken until the vote, but here's a look at what MPs are saying about how they'll vote on Wednesday.
link_name: MPs draw battlelines on abortion motion

Although there are "obvious opportunities," Canada has yet to act on China's call to pen a free-trade deal within a decade, Foreign Affairs Minister John Baird said.

link_name: Canada eyes free-trade deal with China

One Quebec student group says that with tuition hikes officially off the table, it will now champion the idea of free education.

link_name: Quebec students call for free education now that tuition hike is off the table

status_message:
Watch live: The line-up for Peter Lougheed's public memorial service in Calgary began forming early.

Dignitaries and politicians from across the country are gathering at the city's Jubilee Auditorium and overflow seating for the public will be available at a nearby gymnasium.

Lougheed, who was Alberta's 10th premier, died last week at 84.

While serving as premier from 1971 to 1985, Lougheed won the respect of Canadians coast-to-coast.

The service will be broadcast live on Global News, as well as streaming live on our website, starting at 1 pm MST (3 pm EST).
link_name: Watch Live: State memorial for former Alberta premier Peter Lougheed

Among the foundation's previous "world statesman of the year" recipients were Chretien in 2002, Australian prime minister John Howard in 2005, France's Nicolas Sarkozy in 2008 and South Korean President Lee Myung-bak in 2011.

New research suggests the real intent of the historic raid on Dieppe in 1942 was to steal a machine that would help crack top-secret German codes.

Military historian David O'Keefe spent 15 years searching through the once-classified and ultra-secret war files and says the real purpose behind the Dieppe operation – which cost hundreds of Canadian soldiers their lives -- was to capture advanced coding technology from the German headquarters near the French beach.
link_name: Breaking German codes real reason for 1942 Dieppe raid: historian

"I'm actually part Indian," Justin Bieber told Rolling Stone magazine this month. "I think Inuit or something? I'm enough per cent that in Canada I can get free gas." 

Now, the Congress of Aboriginal Peoples is offering to help the 18-year-old singing sensation find out more about his native ancestry, while giving him the benefit of the doubt over his comments to Rolling Stone magazine.
link_name: Group says Justin Bieber wrong about free gas, offers to trace native heritage

status_message:
Team USA's 156-73 thumping of Nigeria on Thursday night has reopened the debate about whether LeBron James, Kobe Bryant and the rest of the star-studded squad are simply too good to play in the Olympics.

The 83-point margin of victory and Carmelo Anthony's 37 points were greater even than anything the original Dream Team, including Michael Jordan and Magic Johnson, managed back in 1992.

YOUR THOUGHTS: Should professional NBA players be allowed to play in the Olympics? Share your thoughts below!

Toronto Mayor Rob Ford is looking to the federal government for help with the city's guns and gangs problem after getting some assistance from the Ontario government.

Premier Dalton McGuinty emerged from a meeting with Ford on Monday to announce $12.5 million a year in permanent funding for anti-violence strategies, including $5 million for Toronto.

Ford says he'll make a similar request for stable federal funding when he meets Prime Minister Stephen Harper today in Toronto.
link_name: Ford, Harper to discuss Toronto's gun crime

A Toronto man's online fundraiser for a New York state school bus monitor who was bullied by her charges has netted close to $700,000 in donations from tens of thousands of people worldwide.

At 12 years old, Jeremiah McDonald decided to record himself having a conversation with his future self. At 32, McDonald uncovers the VHS from 1992 and sits down to answer some of those questions. He even asks his past self a few questions of his own.

Watch the comical, yet moving and memorable recording here.

status_message:
Hydro crews from Canada have joined efforts to restore power to millions of Americans who were still in the dark for a fourth day today.

The blackouts were caused by powerful wind storms that swept through seven eastern U.S. states late Friday, toppling trees and branches into power lines and knocking out big transmission towers and electrical substations.
link_name: Canadian hydro crews join U.S. power restoration efforts after storm

Durham MP and Minister for International Cooperation Bev Oda is stepping down according to a statement issued on the Minister's website on Tuesday.

link_name: MP Bev Oda stepping down

status_message:
Anderson Cooper, who has been reluctant to talk about his personal life in public, revealed that he is gay in an essay posted online on Monday. 

The CNN journalist said he had kept his sexual orientation private for personal and professional reasons, but came to think that remaining silent had given some people a mistaken impression that he was ashamed.
link_name: CNN's Anderson Cooper comes out in Internet post: 'The fact is, I'm gay'

A blog cataloguing a five-month-old infant's list of things to do before she dies has gone viral.  "Avery's Bucket List" was started by the girl's parents as a way of keeping their family and friends updated about their daughter's health.  

On April 6, Avery Canahuati was diagnosed with Type 1 Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA)—an often fatal disease that destroys the nerves controlling voluntary muscle movement, including the respiratory system. Written from infant's perspective but penned by her father, the blog entries are light-hearted, humorous and full of photos that outline some of Avery's "bucket list" adventures and goals.
link_name: 'Avery's Bucket List' blog for five-month-old with Spinal Muscular Atrophy goes viral

He died the following June, a month shy of his 23rd birthday.

Jann Arden says she was kicked out of a Via Rail train "in the middle of nowhere" because she brought her tiny dog, Midi, on board. status_message:
There will soon come a time, not so far into the future, when smartphone users will be able to hold up their device before a crowd of people and instantly find friends and acquaintances with a single click or swipe across a touch screen.  

While it sounds rather magical, facial and iris recognition applications are very real. These apps act like detectives, scanning a crowd to identify people based on information stored in a pre-existing database of photographs and videos.

Are you comfortable with this kind of technology able to identify you?
link_name: Face and iris recognition apps both thrilling and threatening

status_message: Police investigating the Stanley Cup riot in downtown Vancouver have begun serving warrants on media outlets to collect more images of suspected rioters.
link_name: Vancouver Police want media to hand over riot footage

status_message: It's been done with cars, cruises and cash. Now, an Ottawa radio station is giving away a baby to the winner of its latest contest. More than 300 people entered to win a round of $35,000 IVF treatments as part of a contest held by Hot 89.9.
link_name: Ottawa radio station offers couples a chance to win IVF treatments

status_message: Police have charged a 26-year-old man over an apparent racial incident in which a banana was thrown on the ice at Philadelphia Flyers' Wayne Simmonds during an NHL pre-season game.

status_message: Breathe, push and smile for the camera: An Ontario woman plans to stream live video online as she gives birth. Would you watch the webcam childbirth?
link_name: Ontario woman plans webcam childbirth

status_message: The federal government could save billions of dollars if it tackled the roots of poverty, says a new report from a government advisory body. The report from the National Council of Welfare urges the governing Tories to take a long-term "investment" approach to preventing poverty, rather than a short-term program spending approach.
link_name: Ottawa could save billions by tackling roots of poverty: report

status_message: YOUR THOUGHTS: Two of the party leaders in tonight's election debate are rookie leaders. For some Ontarians, the debate was their first chance to get to know Andrea Horwath and Tim Hudak. How did Horwath and Hudak come across? Did Dalton McGuinty meet your expectations in the debate? Share your thoughts below. Global News may publish your comments.
link_name: Ontario leaders talk taxes, students, health care

status_message: A decade-long study of 135,000 men found that those who did not have children had a higher risk of dying from heart disease than those who did, raising new questions about the links between fertility and overall health, U.S. researchers said on Monday.  Is male fertility, or lack thereof, a window into a man's later health? Share your thoughts below.
link_name: Childless men more likely to die of heart problems: study

status_message: Ottawa has finally approved bold new labelling for cigarette packages, making good on last winter's promise to horrify smokers into not smoking. Do you think the new packaging will deter Canadians from smoking? Share your thoughts here.

status_message: The NDP says it will send a file of G8 documents to the Mounties for possible investigation. They will also ask the House of Commons ethics committee to look into money spent in Huntsville, Ont., on projects linked to the international summit in 2010.

status_message: A YouTube video that speaks out against bullying and honours a 14-year old New York boy is going viral. Students in British Columbia made the video "Paws Up Forever Project" after Buffalo teen Jamey Rodemeyer committed suicide.

status_message: Josh Fattal, one of the American hikers who was held captive in Iran for two years and freed a few days ago applauded Iranian authorities for finally making the right decision but said they "don't deserve undue credit for ending what they had no right and no justification to start in the first place." What would you have said if you were in his place?

A major human rights group wants Ottawa to bring criminal charges against former U.S. vice-president Dick Cheney for his alleged role in the torture of Canadian detainees. How do you feel about the group's effort?
link_name: Human rights group urges Ottawa to charge Cheney

status_message: Saskatchewan is partnering with U.S. researchers on a controversial multiple sclerosis treatment known as liberation therapy and plans to send patients south of the border for clinical trials. Canada has a high incidence of multiple sclerosis and, on a per capita basis, the largest number of people with the disease live in Atlantic Canada and on the Prairies. Many Canadians have been travelling abroad to have the treatment performed.
link_name: Sask. to join U.S. on MS liberation therapy clinical trials

status_message:
The Canadian government was expected to announce Thursday Canada's membership in a new international organization dedicated to fighting terrorism.

The new group will become "a counterterrorism network that is as nimble and adaptive as our adversaries," U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said at the inaugural meeting of the Global Counterterrorism Forum, or GCTF.

status_message: Some 81 years after his death, Canada's most decorated war hero will be honoured today with the unveiling of a monument in a Toronto cemetery. First World War flying ace William Barker downed 50 enemy aircraft and received the Victoria Cross after being shot three times when he found himself alone in a dogfight against 15 German planes.
link_name: WWI flying ace's monument to be unveiled in Toronto

status_message: Fourteen-year-old Jamey Rodemeyer, a teenager featured in a high-profile anti-bullying campaign, has died in an apparent suicide.  In an online posting last May, he spoke of the bullying he endured because of his sexuality and tried to encourage other teens to remain hopeful through difficult experiences. The video "It Gets Better" captured attention worldwide.
link_name: Jamey Rodemeyer, teen in anti-bullying PSA video, commits suicide

status_message: Two Americans jailed as spies in Iran were released after more than two years in custody following a court approval of a $1 million bail deal. Iran's state television, Press TV, reported Wednesday morning that Josh Fattal and Shane Bauer have been released.

Sweeping changes to Canada's criminal-justice regime have been introduced in the House of Commons as part of an omnibus Conservative crime bill. The legislation tabled in the Commons includes 9 bills incorporating changes to drug laws, youth sentencing, detention of refugees, parole and house arrest and anti-terrorism measures.

status_message: The Harper government is paying a high-powered management consultant firm almost $90,000 a day for advice on how to save money. Deloitte Inc. was hired on Aug. 15 on a $19.8-million contract to advise the federal cabinet and senior officials on finding enough savings to balance the books by 2014.
link_name: Harper hires consultant at $90,000 a day to trim federal spending

status_message: Surgeons have separated twins born with their heads joined together. There have been other incredible surgeries over the years, including one that involved a 300 lbs cyst.

status_message: A group collecting evidence about missing aboriginal women says the number of victims is on the rise. status_message: Too hot? Don't shoot the messenger. status_message: Statistics Canada says the police-reported crime rate continued a long-term decline last year, dropping five per cent from 2009. It says the national crime rate has been falling steadily for the last 20 years and is now at its lowest level since 1973.

status_message:
On June 6, 1944, under the cover of pre-dawn darkness, British, American, Polish and Canadian forces navigated the choppy waters of the English Channel and stormed 80 km of flat, sandy beach on the coast of Normandy, a region in northern France.

Some 14,000 Canadian troops landed at the second-most heavily fortified of the five landing sites – an eight-kilometer wide strip of beach that included a small fishing port. It was code named Juno Beach.


Read it on Global News: Canadian contribution to D-Day
link_name: Canadian contribution to D-Day

status_message:
Who was the first black president of the U.S.? If you said Winston
Churchill, you're in good company. That's what Danielle Lloyd, former
girlfriend of retired English soccer player Teddy Sheringham, believes.
Some of the other comments made by wives and girlfriends of players are
just as intriguing. Take a look and tell us what you think.
link_name: From the mouths of WAGs

status_message:
In
soccer, calls are made by referees alone and, as result, are subject to
human error. This has led to many botched calls over the years. Here
are some mistakes that will leave you shaking your head.
